author-notes.corresp: Department of Geography, Box 353550, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-3550, USA Email: michaelb@uw.edu

abstract.p: This review considers how recent geographies of sexualities have attended to intersectionality. It documents the unevenness in attention across gender, race, class, age, (dis)ability and religion. Gender and race have received far more attention than others. A series of anxieties is thus raised by this inequity: which and how many intersections are considered, the ironic consequences of those choices, the multiple registers in which these dilemmas occur, and the consequences for other geographies of identity.

sec.title: I Introduction
sec.p: My purpose in this progress report is to consider a potent trend in geographies of sexuality literature over the past seven years: the relating of sexualities with other axes of social identity. I am motivated to do so because there is a steadfast consensus that for geographies of sexuality to be truly queer they cannot focus exclusively on sexuality per se, but must also consider its connections with other dimensions of identity (Browne, 2006; Oswin, 2004). This reflects longstanding critiques within queer theory and activism (Cohen, 1997; DeLauretis, 1991; Manslansan, 2006; Perez, 2005). Broadly speaking, we have moved from concerns over identity politics towards what has, sometimes theoretically, sometimes colloquially, been called intersectionality (Peake, 2010; Valentine, 2007), and so my purpose here is to outline and chronicle the connections between geographies of sexualities and other identities and structural oppressions.

I do this through a series of ‘anxieties’, in the classic spirit of queer geography: to question all assumptions and theoretical moves, no matter how seemingly progressive or radical (Oswin, 2004, 2008). I call them ‘anxieties’ rather than critiques for four reasons. First, they are easily sidestepped but not easily solved; I have no solutions to them. Second, all geographies of sexualities are implicated in them – including my own. Third, my aim is to prompt awareness and reflection about them, rather than to argue against certain strands of literature, individual pieces or intellectual projects per se. Fourth, ‘anxieties’ well names what I do (I am a worrier). These anxieties orbit around the unevenness of intersections we have drawn. I am less concerned with findings and arguments of this scholarship and more with how intersections of identity have been practiced in the literature.

sec.title: II Intersectionality
sec.p: The concept of intersectionality emerges from feminist legal scholarship, specifically from Crenshaw (1991). Allegedly countering identitarianism and essentialism, it conveyed the connections between – and limitations of – one-dimensional, identity-based structures of inequality and oppression. By solely focusing on one axis of oppression and social inequality, researchers risked erasing or discounting other simultaneous ones that positioned individuals quite differently from one another. Crenshaw’s goal was to specify the particularities of experienced oppressions: a black woman is structurally oppressed by both racism and patriarchy in a way that a black man is not. Her concern was preventing the occlusion of certain oppressions when analysis or politics focuses on one in particular.

Valentine (2007) formally put intersectionality on the map for feminist geographies, though certainly work that related sexualities to other identities has been longstanding (e.g. Peake, 1993). She raised a series of potential utilities for the concept, as well as challenges for feminist geographers. Most importantly, she argued that place is a key means through which that specificity is experienced and structured, and that scholars of intersectionality had been lax in attending to that spatiality. Crenshaw herself used the spatial metaphor of the subject standing at the intersection of a variety of ‘streets’ of structures. And while there is some rejection of the term in favor of other metaphors like imbricated, co-constituted, or intermeshed, the term is now used both quite widely (for overviews, see Choo and Marx Ferree, 2010; Dhamoon, 2011) and quite loosely (Jordan-Zachery, 2007; McCall, 2005), including within geography (Hopkins and Noble, 2009; Peake, 2010).

sec.title: III Anxieties
sec.p: Reviewing the recent literature on geographies of sexualities it is clear that we have been following Valentine’s point in stressing how place can bring different identities and subjectivities together ideographically (less work has been done looking at intersectionalities across space). What is troubling, however, is that we have been extremely uneven in which intersections we have investigated, and this is a persistent concern by critics of intersectionality (Yuval-Davis, 2006; Nash, 2008). If, as Valentine argued, places evince particular intersecting identities over others, our own research has certainly not been ubiquitous in exploring all possible intersections.

Given the longstanding theorization of the distinct-but-related positions of sex with gender (Rubin, 1993), it is arguably unsurprising that sexualities’ intersection with gender has been the most consistent trend in the literature. Though there are several studies that frame gays and lesbians as a single population (e.g. Brown et al., 2005; Browne, 2007b, 2010; Cooper, 2006; Gorman-Murray, 2007a, 2007b, 2008a, 2008b; Gorman-Murray and Waitt, 2009; MacDonnell and Andrews, 2006; Mulligan, 2008; O’Reilly and Crutcher, 2006; Oswin, 2010; Simmons, 2008; Waitt, 2005), work on sexualities continues to be dominated by rather separate foci either on lesbians (Bain and Nash, 2007; Browne, 2007a, 2007b; Cauldwell, 2007; Johnston, 2007; Muller, 2007; Nash and Bain, 2007; Podmore, 2006) or on gay men (Brown, 2006, 2009; Catungal and McCann, 2010; Gorman-Murray, 2006, 2011; Holmes, 2009; Miller, 2005; Waitt, 2006), or men who have sex with men (Brickell, 2010; Brown, 2008; Jeyasingham, 2010).

Answering longstanding calls, there has been a spate of work on gender and heterosexual identity (e.g. Cullen, 2006; Ford et al., 2007; Hilsdon and Giridharan, 2008; Hubbard and Whowell, 2008; Visser, 200; Walsh, 2007). Straight women’s sexualities have been the focus of a number of recent studies (Bieri and Gerodetti, 2007; Burges Watson and Stratford, 2008; Crowley and Kitchin, 2008; Dando, 2009; Drummond, 2006; Dua, 2007; Gaetano, 2008; Hubbard and Whowell, 2008; Radley et al., 2006; Richardson et al., 2009; Rydstrom, 2006; Walker, 2005). The focus of this work is often particular populations of women and how their sexualities are controlled or disciplined in patriarchal and heteronormative ways (Boyd, 2010; Cullen, 2006; Faria, 2008; Radley et al., 2006). A fainter, more recent trend is a focus on heterosexual men (Del Casino, 2007b; Henry and Berg, 2006; Malam, 2008a, 2008b). Comparable work on different sexualities across the same gender is extremely rare (Hibbins, 2005).

A powerful point in work on the intersectionality of sexuality and gender is the exposure of privileges of certain identities amidst heteronormativity and homophobia, reflecting feminist theory’s call for intersectional work to acknowledge both oppression and privilege in intersections of identities (Baird, 2006; Holmes, 2009; Nash, 2005; Podmore, 2006). Though there are dangers of ‘the oppression olympics’ (Hancock, 2007; Marx Ferree, 2009) (whereby subjects are additively valorized by the number of oppressions they face), or of the ‘race to innocence’ (Dhamoon, 2011) (where intersectional critiques target some but not others), this scholarship reminds us that taking polyvalent power relations seriously suggests few subjects are without some structural privilege or oppression (Elder, 2002).

Most recently trans identities have complicated geographies of gender and sexualities (Browne and Lim, 2010; Browne et al., 2010; Doan, 2007, 2010; Hines, 2010; Nash, 2010; Nash and Bain, 2007; Rooke, 2010). They show how sexist and transphobic homonormative gay and lesbian spaces can be, and suggest alternative spaces for support and security (Rooke, 2010). They also challenge our assumptions about the stability of gender while gender and sexuality are intersected. Doan’s (2010) powerful autoethnography is a masterful piece in this regard.

Race and ethnicity’s intersection with sexuality has received acute attention, reflecting the intense relations between nation, imperialisms, globalization and sexualities (Bassi, 2006; Caluya, 2008; Haritaworn, 2007; Hilsdon and Giridharan, 2008; Hyndman et al., 2010; Jazeel, 2005; Mulligan, 2008; Olund, 2010; O’Reilly and Crutcher, 2006; Oswin, 2005, 2006, 2010; Puar, 2006, 2007; Raimondo, 2005, 2010; Rasmussen, 2006; Saad and Carter, 2005; Sandell, 2010). This spate of work also responds to the overall whiteness of queer scholarship and racisms within queer work (Ferguson, 2004; Perez, 2005). It has especially highlighted the ways homonormative identities and spaces can be deeply racist and privilege an invisible whiteness (Bassi, 2006; Caluya, 2008; Catungal and McCann, 2010). In this way it traces the uneven ways race articulates with sexualities across space (Tucker, 2010), and how hetero and homonormativity work unevenly across differently raced figures. Puar’s (2006, 2007) fascinating work on American homonormativities after 9/11 is agenda-setting in this regard. Another common theme is tracing the way homophobia deploys in projects of ethnic or national purity (Mulligan, 2008; Waitt, 2005). Like work on the intersection of sexualities and genders, this research also considers the unique combinations of privilege and oppression where identities intersect. And it is here we see interesting theoretical work that problematizes intersectionality.

A mounting argument in the geographies of sexualities is that research on sexuality must consider intersections with race. Indeed, several geographers have rejected Crenshaw’s concept of intersectionality because they claim it actually dangerously separates race and sexuality (Olund, 2010; Oswin and Rouhani, 2011; Puar, 2007). In what McCall (2005) refers to as ‘anticategorical intersectionality’, they surmise that the metaphor of intersection presumes an empirical or conceptual separation of the two, which is ironically essentializing. By separating strands of identity, even analytically, an unhelpful additive notion of oppression results (Choo and Marx Ferree, 2010; Nash, 2008; cf. Sayer, 1997). Such separation obscures important co-constitutive tendencies. Indeed, a brilliant feature of this work is its careful documentation of how the regulation and structuration of one dimension of identity has been prosecuted through the other. Following McWhorter (2009) these critics argue the couplet as indissolvable. Whether other axes of identity are just as inseparable from sexuality and whether foregrounding sexualities’ co-constitution with race obscures other co-constitutions remains unclear and undiscussed.

Beyond gender and race, however, other axes of identity and structures of oppression have received far less attention. Work at the intersection of class and sexuality has been fascinating but rare recently (Binnie, 2011; Cooper, 2009; Dando, 2009; Ford et al., 2007; Malam, 2008a; Richardson et al., 2009; Simmons, 2008). Taylor’s (2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011) excellent work has traced the lines of privilege and oppression at the intersection of lesbians’ and working-class positions, showing how class divisions fracture collective lesbian identity and spaces in both material and emotional ways. Certainly the class privilege of many gay men and lesbians has been highlighted in research on homonormativity (Browne, 2006; Casey, 2009; Holmes, 2009; Nash, 2005; Twin Cities GLBT Oral Histories Project, 2010; Visser, 2008; Waitt, 2006). The intersection of heterosexualities and poor or working-class identities has also been researched (e.g. Boyd, 2010; Dando, 2009; Richardson et al., 2009). Class privileges, it has been well documented, can offer significant resources to combat homophobia (Bassi, 2006; Casey, 2009; Oswin, 2005; Simmons, 2008; Taylor, 2005).

Work on sexualities’ intersections with age has been rare and uneven across specific groups (Ford et al., 2007; Gorman Murray, 2008b; Thomas, 2011). These often focus on hetero-patriarchal powers directed at controlling the young, especially women (Rydstrom, 2006). By contrast, work on the sexualities of older people remain conspicuously absent, though research in other fields suggests this is a potentially important intersection for geographies of sexuality to consider (e.g. Horden and Street, 2007). Perhaps the graying of the baby boomers will shift this focus?

Other axes of identity are only just beginning to be intersected with sexuality, despite longstanding research agendas on them within geography. The intersections of sexualities with (dis)ability are surprisingly understudied. This is puzzling because historically a central disciplining feature of dissident and non-normative sexualities has been its coding as illness and dis-ease (Del Casino, 2007a). Within the geographies of sexualities, however, there have been fascinating exceptions. Sothern (2007a, 2007b) and Del Casino (2007b) offer intriguing examples of the illiberal challenges the disabled body poses to both homo and heteronormativity. Lewis (2009) has explored the health issues around gay men, including mental health issues. And recent work on disabilities suggests there are quite important intersections between geographies of sexualities and (dis)ability (Chouinard, 2009; Davidson, 2010; Wiesel, 2009). The association of sexuality with particular forms of physical ableism and corporeal beauty surely suggests important normativities at the intersection of sexualities and (dis)ability that warrant considerable further investigation (McRuer, 2006). The intersection of sexualities with religion is even rarer, though there is an increasing amount of work in this area (Rouhani, 2007; Valentine et al., 2010; Vanderbeck et al., 2011). As religion is an institution that has been central to the regulation of normative sexualities, this lacuna is surprising, especially given the resurgence of interest in geographies of religion across critical human geography.

This overall unevenness within geographies of sexualities produces a worry over just which identities we choose to intersect with sexualities. Dharmoon (2011) notes the common focus on ‘the triad’ of race/class/gender to the exclusion of others, and there is surely evidence above that the geographies of sexuality prioritize this trinity. A related concern is over how many intersections to consider in our research (Dhamoon, 2011; Yuval-Davis, 2006). Across the geographies of sexualities there are impressive examples of research that consider multiple points of intersection (Fitzgerald, 2007; Hubbard and Whowell, 2008; Malam, 2008a, 2008b; Nash, 2010; Oswin, 2010; Puar, 2007, 2009; Tucker, 2009), and surely this approach reduces concerns over exclusions and elisions. However, how many is enough? If the point of intersectionality is to capture intersections of multiple privileges and/or oppressions, why not consider as many as possible? And yet, Davis (2008: 77) warns of the ‘infinite regress’ of any truly intersectional piece. Furthermore, these questions quickly lead to another worry: on what basis does one choose which identities to include or exclude? Intersectionality has been relentlessly criticized for its lack of clear methodological direction (Hancock, 2007; Jordan-Zachary, 2007; Nash, 2008; Yuval-Davis, 2006), which leads to the possibility that there may be theoretical justification for choices, but here too anxieties emerge.

Regardless, another worry arises around the consequences of our choices. Intentional or not, what are we saying theoretically about sexualities’ relations with other structures of oppression or privilege in deciding which or how many intersections to consider? Are we prioritizing or ranking, and, if so, what are the justifications for this hierarchy (Jordan-Zachary, 2007)? These questions are, of course, especially apposite in an intellectual context of poststructuralism and queer theory that (a) resists such foundational and potentially essentializing hierarchies and (b) insists that present-absences in texts speak just as loudly as presences and authorial intentions. The fallout from our intersectional choices (however well considered) is the possible – and quite ironic – reinstatement of identity politics, albeit co-constituted ones (Archer, 2005; Francis, 2001; McCall, 2005).

Still another worry is that these issues manifest simultaneously across a variety of registers in our research. One is linguistic. As Harlan (1991) notes, language and representation are thoroughly spatial: signification must be ordered, which connotes and denotes a hierarchy of items. Another is methodological (Hancock, 2007): how does our research design and data affect intersectional possibilities in our work? A third is conceptual: are certain identities more foundational than others, which are derivative? And a fourth is political: are we saying that certain identities and/or intersections are more important than others? Strategic (spatial) essentialisms provide a partial solution (Veronis, 2007), but do not solve the unevenness or (unintended) consequences of our intersectional choices.

A final anxiety is more diffuse, but it also echoes critiques of intersectionality. Nash (2008) argues that the figure of the black woman has come to be thought of as quintessentially intersectional, while others are not. Do our complexities in geographies of sexuality leave LGBTQ figures as mere synecdoches for intersectionality within critical geography? To be sure, intersectionality is not exclusive to geographies of sexuality, but it is also surely the case that not all geographies of identity incorporate sexualities into their intersections regularly. If other geographies fail to consider the possible efficacies of homophobia and heteronormativity themselves, while geographies of sexualities persistently do, might sexualities be further marginalized in the discipline, inadvertently? Schlemper and Monk (2011), for instance, document how rarely sexuality gets considered in the arena of ‘diversity’ in American geography. Of course, a more hopeful outcome is that other geographies of identity look towards geographies of sexuality as a model for expanding their own intersectional gaps and omissions.

sec.title: IV Conclusion
sec.p: My purpose in this progress report is not to shame or castigate. Geographies of sexualities have been quite intrepid in considering how identities intersect. But the work has been uneven, and this leaves all of us with dilemmas around choice, quantity, and unintended consequences in any direction forward. As Davis (2008) argues, however, a fulsome benefit of an intersectional perspective is in its invitation to auto-critique and self reflection. So a hopeful point of conclusion might be that we may work on our intersectional anxieties in ever more careful ways – but always in ways that work towards understanding the full depth and range of sexualities.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Thanks to Larry Knopp, Natalie Oswin, and Sarah Radcliffe for their extremely helpful comments and suggestions. Andrew Childs provided invaluable research assistance.
